my background in addition to my title at

it's a runtime that we'll talk about

we could all agree that of course the
history of containers doesn't begin with
docker
I mean you've probably heard of LXE or

you know mountain namespaces pit
namespaces but I think we can all agree

really kind of exposed that interest in
these technologies that had existed and
people have been playing with for maybe
ten years or more and so that brought us

talking about docker we're writing
docker files people are our packaging

wasn't the only container runtime
it was definitely a very popular one but
rocket from Corliss was announced I
think in December 2014 2014 they came on
the scene with some different ideas
about how to run a container using those
same features and Linux but yet with a

identify the container and then of
course in more recent years we have

but predating that cloud foundry which

still is a platform as-a-service open
source project they were running

and then in the high performance
computing space now there's singularity
and a few others I didn't had their
logos but here's all these runtimes lots
of different ways to run containers and
the worry in 2015 is what if we end up
in a world where once you commit to a
tool I can't switch to another runtime
you know we all have different ideas
about what it means to create a
container image or what it means to
start a container process and so we
really wanted this unifying definition
of what it means to run a container and
so really that's how the OCI was born
the open container initiative similar to
the CNC F parented by the Linux
Foundation so officially we are the OCI
is a Linux Foundation collaborative
project and again the idea was we'd like
all these participants to get on the
same page with respect to what it means
to define how to run a container or how
to build a container image and so it
started there in 2015 with starting to
build a runtime specification a actual
reference implementation which many of
you have heard if you've heard people
talk about run see that was a set of
code that was in the docker engine prior
2015 it was actually a a subdirectory
called Lib container which is now if you
go to the github project for Runcie
you'll still see that Lib container
subdirectory and many of those
implementations have been the same now
for many years in addition to run C so
this sort of default way to run the
specified container the OCI created an
image format specification and now more
recently we're also hopefully finalizing
a distribution spec and so that's all
work that that's gone on all the way
back to 2015 and so much of that work
was finalized in 2017 with the release
of the runtime spec 1.0 and the image
spec 1.0 so you can go back and see the
announcements and read the blog posts
but this is really the the culmination
of what we wanted we wanted a way for
everyone to agree
what's a container image how do we
specify what it means to run a container
and so that's really given us a common
substrate on which we've built a lot of
tools so these specifications whether
we're talking about Linux Microsoft has
been fully involved in the OCI so what
it means to run a Windows container is
also part of the OCI spec and that gives
us a handful of runtimes today that that
I've listed here some of them not all of
them and a set of registries you know
things like docker hub things like
project harbour J frog various public
clouds have their own registry
implementations quai all these are
running on a common substrate so that I
don't have to pick one tool and stick
with it and I can't switch until I sort
of reformat or or migrate my images or
my container definitions to a different
format so that's a great place that's
that's definitely what we wanted and
just to give you a kind of quick view
into where the OCI is going we're not
necessarily done yet
this year we have
expanded with a new artifacts project so
defining other things that can be stored
in in registries today you may have seen
in other talks mention of C NAB the
cloud native application bundle spec
there are those in the community
interested in in software bundles like
SPD X like what's in my image and so
there are some common formats and so a
way to define the kinds of artifacts we
want to store in registries that's a new
part of the OCI that's actually gotten a

providers and their registry teams we're
finalizing the distribution spec so
think of this as the way that runtimes
today talked to like docker hub that
HTTP API is now going to be the OCI

other sort of proposed ways to image to

anyway there's a lot of things that the
OCI will continue to do hopefully to

we like that we have the
interoperability to use docker or creo

OCI let's turn our attention to
kubernetes what runs your container and
kubernetes you probably know this but
but definitely there are those who who
aren't aware of this but kubernetes is
just the orchestrator it has no built in
container engine in kubernetes it's
always relied on a runtime and for
almost you know back to the origins of
kubernetes that's always been docker and
was kind of the architectural picture of
what that looked like
the Kubla which is installed on your
worker node when the API server the core
part of kubernetes wants to schedule a
pod on your note and ask the couplet to
actually do that work and so if you look
in the kubernetes codebase you can see
this you know docker shim subdirectory
which has this loose sort of api with
the docker engine hey docker please go
create this container here's the image
reference here's kind of the way we want
to run it and that was great when all we
had was docker but then again we had
rocket and so there was a rocket
Nettie's which had a way to drive the
further couplet to drive rocket but
obviously it would be a bad situation to
have a kubernetes source tree that had
separate code for how to drive all kinds
of different container runtimes and so
that's when the kubernetes CRI was
decided upon and announced in late 2016
so you can go read this blog post about
the kubernetes community and
specifically sig note creating the
container runtime interface which is
effectively an api that say you decided
to write your own container runtime this
is the set of api's that you would have
to implement to be a container runtime
for kubernetes again simple things like
start a container stop a container pull
an image from a registry and so there's
a set of specific tasks that a runtime
must do on behalf of the coolant that's
created by the CRI in API and so this is
a picture I've shown several times and
tried to update to make it clearer but
there are obviously a set of runtimes
today that that implement the CRI they
sort of loosely default back to docker
container D and creo as the main ones
but there's a couple of new additions in
the last year the singularity team so
again this is a hyper form
it's computing runtime that has a CRI
implementation now that drives their own
container engine which also now has an
OC I compliant implementation as well
but if you think about the couplet again
wanting to talk to a socket that
implements the CRI API you can see that
for container D there's a CRI plug-in
that handles that for creo the creo
engine handles that docker shim will
probably be sunset at some point it's
not truly an implementation the CRI but
in fact it's sort of the de facto
standard so when people report a bug to
container D or creo it tends to be hey
when I use docker underneath kubernetes
this is the way things work and so the
other CRI CRI implementations tend to
try and meet that expected behavior the
reason I added a second entry for
container D is because we have a shim
API in container D that allows you to
plug in other sandbox Isolators like
cata containers again lightweight
hypervisors AWS created the Firecracker
project about a year ago they also have
a shim for container D Google's G Weiser
team also has a shim so that you can run

Weiser and so say you were building your
own cluster there's ways to tell the
couplet hey by the way here's my
container runtime here's its socket
where you can talk to the CRI API and
then as a user there's some interesting
new features in recent kubernetes

or firecracker for this pod I'd actually
like to use this runtime and there's
also some ways to do that with
annotations so that's great we have a

for containers but where are things
today and again
just to be clear docker is still the
lion's share of usage of container

and so as the if you go and read the
